Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: High-order Phonon Scattering and Highly Nonequilibrium Carrier Transport in Two-dimensional Electronic and Optoelectronic Materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: Semiconductor research and development over the past several decades have enabled widespread use of electronic devices in society. However, the semiconductor industry is facing significant challenges, such as the difficulty in dissipating the large amount of heat generated in silicon electronic chips. The challenges have motivated the investigation of emerging two-dimensional (2D) electronic materials because of their superior electronic and thermal properties. One representative 2D material is graphene that is made of a single layer of carbon atoms. However, compared to the abundant knowledge of silicon electronics, there is only limited understanding of heat dissipation in 2D electronic materials. Therefore, the goal of this project is to establish an in-depth understanding of the distinctly different heat generation and dissipation processes in 2D materials and devices. The obtained knowledge will be used to develop open-source simulation tools, enhance online courses and classroom instruction, and develop hands-on outreach activities to improve the recruitment and training of a diverse population of next-generation workforce in thermal engineering.<br/><br/>The goal of this project is to understand the unique fundamental mechanisms underlying heat generation and conduction processes in emerging 2D electronic and optoelectronic materials, including graphene and transition metal dichalcogenides (TMD). Specifically, three outstanding questions that are relevant to the performance and thermal reliability of 2D electronic and optoelectronic materials will be addressed: (1) the importance of four-phonon scattering processes in graphene and other 2D materials; (2) the length scales for different phonon polarizations and electronic excitations to establish local thermal equilibrium in 2D semiconductors; and (3) the phonon mode conversion and transmission processes across the dimensionally mismatched interfaces between a 2D layer and its 3D support. The questions will be addressed via first principles and atomistic theoretical calculations that resolve the modal scattering and coupling behaviors of phonons and electrons, in conjunction with thermal transport and inelastic light scattering measurements of graphene and TMD. Improved understanding of the three specific questions helps to build the foundation for modeling and controlling heat dissipation processes in 2D materials and devices.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The electrical energy consumption by semiconductor devices are converted into high-density heating that causes local hot spots and degrades the device performance and thermomechanical reliability. At the microscopic level, the performance of electronic and optoelectronic devices is governed by the interactions between hot electrons excited by an external field and different polarizations of phonons, which are the energy quanta of lattice vibration. Compared to the knowledge in hot electron relaxation mechanisms in silicon electronic and III-V compound semiconductor optoelectronic devices, there has been only limited understanding of electron-phonon and phonon-phonon coupling processes in emerging two-dimensional (2D) layered electronic and thermal management materials such as transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) and graphene. In this project, we have carried out both Raman spectroscopy and electro-thermal microbridge measurements to probe phonon-mediated energy transport processes in emerging electronic, optoelectrical, and thermal management materials. The experiments have obtained results that are used by our Purdue collaborators to establish detailed theoretical models of highly non-equilibrium energy carrier transport processes.

In one experiment, we investigate the effects of hot optical phonons in the Raman spectra of molybdenum disulphide (MoS2), a prototypical semiconducting TMD, and distinguish them from those caused by thermally-induced compressive stress. The observed moderate thermal non-equilibrium among different phonon polarizations agrees with a first-principle based multi-temperature model of our Purdue collaborator. The findings from this collaborative work provide detailed insight into the energy relaxation processes in this emerging 2D TMD electronic and optoelectronic material and clarify an important question in micro-Raman thermal transport measurements of this and other 2D materials.  

In another combined theoretical and experimental study, our Purdue collaborators employ first-principles methods that explicitly consider scattering processes involving not only three phonons but also four phonons in graphene in their calculation of the Raman linewidth. Their calculation shows that consideration of four-phonon scattering leads to opposite temperature dependence of the Raman linewidth compared to prior calculations that neglected four-phonon processes. In conjunction, we provide Raman measurement data on suspended monolayer graphene to support the temperature dependence predicted by our Purdue collaborators. This work reveals that four-phonon scattering plays an indispensable role in optical phonon energy relaxation in pristine graphene.

In addition, our Purdue collaborators and others have recently predicted  ultrahigh thermal conductivity in semi-metallic theta-phase  tantalum nitride (theta-TaN). This theoretical prediction has motivated us to pursue high-pressure synthesis of theta-TaN samples. The thermal conductivity measured in initial polycrystalline theta-TaN samples is already more than one-order of magnitude higher than the values reported for other TaN phases and comparable to commercial polycrystalline silicon carbide materials that are used to fabricate high-temperature ceramic heat exchangers. However, the measured values are still more than a factor of five lower than the theoretical prediction for defect-free single-crystal theta-TaN. In order to better understand the phonon dynamics that control the lattice thermal conductivity, we employ Raman spectroscopy to probe the phonon modes in the sample and use the defect-mediated Raman scattering signature to understand the defects in these samples.

Meanwhile, our theoretical collaborators at Purdue University have recently calculated lower basal-plane thermal conductivity of monolayer suspended graphene than the ultrahigh value reported for bulk graphite. Past measurements of thermal conductivity of suspended graphene are based on either Raman thermometry measurements or two-probe resistive thermometry measurements, which contain large measurement uncertainties. To overcome these challenges in thermal transport measurements of suspended graphene as well as its carbon nanotube (CNT) cousin, we establish a differential electro-thermal bridge measurement method to enhance the signal to noise ratio and reduce the measurement uncertainty. These recent progresses have enhanced our capability to accomplish our persistent goal of measuring the intrinsic thermal conductivity of suspended high-quality few-layer graphene and CNT samples for comparison with our Purdue collaborators’ four-phonon theoretical calculations.

These findings from the thermal transport studies of several emerging functional materials are valuable for electro-thermal co-design of next-generation electronic and optoelectronic materials. This project has provided opportunities for three students to receive training in nanoscale thermal transport measurements, inelastic light scattering measurements, nanomaterials growth, and nanofabrication. Among them, one woman student has completed her PhD dissertation and moved on to post-doctoral training in another university. An Hispanic American student has been supported to complete a joined BS and MS degree in mechanical engineering and is currently pursuing PhD Study. Moreover, this project has allowed the team to participate in outreach activities to broaden participation in science and engineering.
